status.full_text: @lara_amalia Hast Du einen Link zum Rezept?
@benjamin Ja, gutes Beispiel wie unser Arbeitsplatz noch "optimiert" wird. Das zu Hinterfragen und einzud√§mmen wird schwierig.
Today at #tagderarbeit we celebrate the fight of the working class for a better society. Here is something important I'd like you to do:
Inform yourself about your rights as a worker and employee! Neither your employer nor our education will teach you these sufficiently.
Learn about regulations for workplace safety and conditions because your health is key to a happy life.
Learn about overtime: you do not have to work overtime. The exceptions to that rule are rare and really hard to justify.
Learn about how to deal with harassment or if you are target of or witnesses power abuse. Start talking to coworkers and find allies.
Know that you are allowed to talk about your salary! Share this information with coworkers to understand if you are paid fair.
Learn about "Bildungsurlaub": you get extra vacation for taking education courses.
A tough one: Hold yourself and your employer to high moral standards. Don't help in shady or illegal business. Never stop asking questions!
It's ok (and free!) to seek help in case you feel stressed. More people then ever are hospitalized for psychic treatment in Germany.
Organize! More and more individualized (and sub-contracted) work disconnects the workforce. Power comes from joining forces on issues.

@robsblog @mayflowergmbh Absolutely!
Equal pay sounds good, but is hardly what you really want.

@robsblog @mayflowergmbh Buffer has updated their scheme recently: https://t.co/iRikcU85lF ‚Ä¶ good ideas in there.
Transparency, above all, is key.

I can understand your feeling.

I'm curious though, why you personally would need it?

@SeifLotfy And I'll join you!

So, I've done a few programming tests now, and one things that strikes me as really odd is the evaluation of knowledge about the Big O. ‚§µÔ∏è
It's unquestionable that I should be able so solve an algorithmic problem correctly.
But what does implementing a performant solution in withing a short period of time proof?

I either know the optimal solution already
or I'll Google it.
What's the point in that?
I'll always prefer the most straight forward, easy to read and understand solution for any given problem
than a hard to decipher blurb of lines which can take a while to understand for other developers.
Because, in the real world, you will in most cases have the help of a VM that does the optimization for you, or:
you have the time AND the data to figure out the real bottlenecks of an algorithm.
And in that case, the implementation of the solution will probably be highly coupled to the specific features of the language.

@mtschammer @fasterthanlime That's the point. It's important top understand what an ORM can do, and what you shouldn't do with it.

Because, yeah, you buy a car only for the torque measured at the crankshaft:
https://t.co/95Tj6xr5XZ
@mtschammer @fasterthanlime That's what the diagram says. An ORM covers ~50% SQL and maybe 80% of your object mapping needs: so it covers 40% of your problem domain.

@wolframkriesing Here I two things I've used in the past, both have one thing in common, they are tied to the sourcecode and convey knowledge through code.

@wolframkriesing 1: https://t.co/sG6DlAoxDW
I use it to create model diagrams, but these diagrams are generate from simple text files.

@wolframkriesing These text files are easy to update, and evolve with your domain moddel.
You can start with simple words and later add more information,
@wolframkriesing to relations, models and about boundaries.

@wolframkriesing 2: BDD / Gherkin
By describing the behaviour of the system in plain, parseable english, you use domain language do desribe the system.
@wolframkriesing Since this is also driving tests, you'll end up with a compact documentation of your system that is always up to date.
